Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Patient-Specific Instrumentation with Conventional Techniques in Unicompartmental Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: 60 patients with a mean age of 63 years (range 54–72) and mean BMI of 28 kg/m² were randomised

Participants.evidence: 60 patients with a mean age of 63 years (range 54–72) and mean BMI of 28 kg/m²

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive UKA using either PSI or conventional instrumentation

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether patient-specific instrumentation (PSI) improves outcomes compared to conventional techniques.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was gait parameters assessed with three-dimensional analysis at 1 year.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to the intervention.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 60 patients with a mean age of 63 years (range 54–72) and mean BMI of 28 kg/m² were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: no significant differences were observed in gait parameters between the PSI and conventional groups: double limb support (31% vs. 30%; p = 0.67) and walking speed (1.59 m/s vs. 1.57 m/s; p = 0.41).
